title: Meter Command
description: LLMs that both understand your data and design systems. Here unifying rich chat experience with open canvas space. Interfaces will become less cluttered, only showing you what you need to see or take action on at any moment.

title: GPU visualization
description: It's easy to get desensitized to large numbers. If we sit back and think about it, often we start to feel the immensity. Or you can just show them. And even better, bring them into your world as well.

title: Simulation modeling
description: Simulations give rise to complex possiblity spaces, and emergent behavior. Sliders to control key variables of the simulation, coupled with the ability to see the range of possible effects of that variable at different strengths seems to provide a good way to build intuition about the system's dynamics.

title: Interface dimensionality
description: Digital interface controls can come in a wider range of shapes and forms to navigate possibility spaces. They can match the underlying shape of the variable(s) you want to control, and can be extended as the need arises.

title: Quord
description:
Harmony exploration machine
What I love about this tool is how playful it makes it to discover harmonies and synth sounds. The space of possibilities enabled by the interface provides plenty of variation and taste to emerge. Quord doesn't expose too many knobs to the user, but the ones that it does capture key variables of sound that provide a lot of control in a bounded space where most possiblities are quite interesting to listen to.

title: Search space
description:
An interface defines the metric of search space
How we can act and what possible states we can reach is bounded by the set of controls we have at our disposal. By the interface we have to communicate our intentions. An elegant interface provides a set of controls that capture the key variables of a possibility space; that slice reality at the right level of abstraction.

Natural language interfaces provide a way to teleport to a configuration of variables in a state space; with the ability to fuzzily update those variables to find desired states.

title: Text synthesizers
description: LLMs give us entirely new semantic variables that we can assign dials, sliders, knobs and controls to. Combinations of these variables can be used to increase, decrease and mix qualities together to explore a space of possibilities.

title: Luma Labs Landing Page
description: By blurring the separation between landing page and product, it makes for a very smooth narrative flow. After learning about what the product does, it's only natural to want to see the product in action.

title: Dynamic Input
description: How can we be sure that natural language communication with machines correctly captures our intent? Interfaces can be used to allow machines to communicate their understanding of our intent, and allow us to correct them if they are wrong.

title: Nothing Phone: Essential Space
description:
Frictionless text and voice notes attached to onscreen media.

All captures are organized in a single space. Tasks and todolists are automatically created. This is a smooth, fluid experience that maps to a user's intentions.

Elegant usage of single press, double press and long press gestures to capture text, go to your space, and capture voice respectively.

title: No one wants to take notes
description:
'Note-taking' isn't a thing. No one wants to 'take notes.' We have something else we are trying to get done, and it happens to involve text. A note-taking app does a lousy job of supporting whatever that is.

Every note carries with it an intention. We want to remember to take some action, keep track of some process, or capture some idea to return to. However, without a clear way to return to the note, intentions can be lost.

title: Lumalabs image prompt bar
description:
I like their treatment of the digital materiality of the images. Tossing them above the bar with a slight tilt makes it feel lighter, less formal, less at stake and benefits the feeling of remixing something

Also the way they introduce the video descriptions of pan actions after a short delay. Enough time that a familiar user won't see the tutorial, but someone who is hovering over it confused will almost immediately see it.

title: The Design of Everyday Things
description: Good design requires good communication, especially from machine to person, indicating what actions are possible, what is happening, and what is about to happen

title: The communal science lab
description:
The greatest leaps in the progress of civilization have come from new forms for seeing and discussing ideas — written language, mathematical notation, interactive computing — which we might broadly call "user interfaces".

An interface gives physical form to invisible concepts, and in science, invisible and intangible concepts abound.

title: Maeda Laws of Simplicity
description:
Thought provoking, provides directions for improving designs, some overlap with Dieter Rams

Generally, am curious to find more "rules" like this to use simply as prompts that might suggest interesting design/research directions.

title: Dieter Rams 10 Principles
description: Sitting with these. What still feels relevant to interaction design? What principles should be added? Perhaps Maeda's Laws of Simplicity?

title: OP-1 Teenage Engineering
description:
Both functional and beautiful interface design. See Tombola for one of my favorites.

Inspiring to see how expressive they can make a limited set of physical controls. Reminds me of Dieter Rams' principle, "Good design is as little design as possible".

title: Studio Moniker + Coinbase brand identity
description: I like the brightness and boldness of the typography, color and geometries. The interfaces give everything a slightly futuristic energy + the digital billboard type transitions

title: Push pop press - interactive book
description: Big picture + details on demand, persistent digital materiality, interactive images + figures that are slightly off the page to signifier interactivity, information communicated through interaction allowing for interactive analysis

title: Active video player
description: Using multiple representations to give context to the video narrative. All of them are synchronized, and help answer questions + build a better model of the narrative. A kind of peripheral vision.

title: Hyperbind
description:
"As you scroll through the webpage in the left pane, each of its links appears in the right pane."

I like the idea of reducing the friction to view referenced materials while avoiding the overwhelm of having 100s of links open as tabs. "scrolling and opening links in a single gesture"

title: Visual Program Behavior
description: The realization that such a simple rule was behind what I would have assumed was quite complex. Very promising to walk through a complex process like this and grasp how it works almost immediately.
